instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> BACKLIGHT problem......
threads.message:
hi.........i have macbook pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>,,,,part no <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A...BEFORE THIS LAPTOP CAME WITH BACKLIGHT ISUUE....also display brocken...
then i trace the board..found <CAPACITOR>C8473</CAPACITOR> is short...then i replace the capacitor...backlight is ok....but after 1 weak this mac came return with same backlight issue.....
voltages 
<CAPACITOR>C8473</CAPACITOR>:-58v ok
also i check with another display...so..what next

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> BACKLIGHT problem......
threads.message:
58V means no connection with LEDS strip.
If already tested with compatible LCD assembly, then change the small video cable.

Be sure to get good contacts at J8500.
Check continuity from J8500 to <DIODE>D8410</DIODE>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> BACKLIGHT problem......
threads.message:
How I check the connection from j8500 to <DIODE>D8410</DIODE>..........because there is many connection pins in j8500..
If there is connection OK with led strip...how much volt come in <CAPACITOR>C8473</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> BACKLIGHT problem......
threads.message:
Each line has a proper name to search in pdf.

Normal voltage is close to 45V; can only be measured with LCD connected.
